subsection.title: Coefficient Matrix and Augmented Matrix of a System
subsection.p:
We will use matrices to solve systems of linear equations. For a system of linear equations of the form
a_1 x + b_1 y + c_1 z \amp= d_1 a_2 x + b_2 y + c_2 z \amp= d_2 a_3 x + b_3 y + c_3 z \amp= d_3
the matrices
\begin{bmatrix} a_1\amp b_1\amp c_1 \\ a_2 \amp b_2 \amp c_2 \\ a_3 \amp b_3\amp c_3 \end{bmatrix} \text{ and } \left[ \begin{array}{@{}ccc|c@{}} a_1\amp b_1\amp c_1 \amp d_1\\ a_2 \amp b_2 \amp c_2 \amp d_2\\ a_3 \amp b_3\amp c_3 \amp d_3 \end{array}\right]
are called the coefficient matrixcoefficient matrix and the augmented matrixaugmented matrix, respectively. Each row of the augmented matrix represents one of the equations of the system. For example, the augmented matrix of the system

The augmented matrix of this last system, which has all zero entries in the lower left corner (below the diagonal), is said to be in upper triangular formupper triangular form. As we saw in , it is easy to find the solution of such a system by back-substitution.

subsection.title: Elementary Row Operations
subsection.p: The method of elimination depends on two properties of linear systems that allow us to change one system into an equivalent one, that is, one that has the same solutions as the original system.

li.p: Multiplying a linear equation by a (nonzero) constant does not change its solutions. That is, any solution of the equation ax + by = c is also a solution of the equation kax + kby = kc

Adding (or subtracting) two linear equations does not change their common solutions. That is, any solution of the system
a_1 x + b_1 y \amp = c_1 a_2 x + b_2 y \amp = c_2
is also a solution of the equation (a_1 + a_2)x + (b_1 + b_2)y = c_1 + c_2

subsection.p:
These properties apply to linear systems of any size. Thus, we can perform the following operations on the equations of a system:
Multiply both sides of an equation by a nonzero real number.
Add a constant multiple of one equation to another equation.
Interchange two equations.
Because each equation of the system corresponds to a row in the augmented matrix, the three operations above correspond to three elementary row operations for the augmented matrix. We can perform one or more of these operations on a matrix without changing the solution of the system it represents.

statement.p: Use row operations to form an equivalent matrix with the given elements: \left[ \begin{array}{@{}cc|c@{}} 1 \amp -4 \amp -5 \\ 3 \amp 6 \amp 3\\ \end{array}\right] \longrightarrow \left[ \begin{array}{@{}cc|c@{}} 1 \amp -4 \amp -5 \\ 0 \amp \text{?} \amp \text{?} \\ \end{array}\right]

Use row operations to form an equivalent matrix with the given elements: \left[ \begin{array}{@{}cc|c@{}} -1 \amp -3 \amp 7 \\ -2 \amp 4 \amp -6\\ \end{array}\right] \longrightarrow \left[ \begin{array}{@{}cc|c@{}} -1 \amp -3 \amp 7 \\ 0 \amp \text{?} \amp \text{?} \\ \end{array}\right]

Use row operations on the first matrix to form an equivalent matrix in upper triangular form. \left[ \begin{array}{@{}ccc|c@{}} 1 \amp -3 \amp 1 \amp -4 \\ 3 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp 8\\ 2 \amp -2 \amp 3 \amp -1\\ \end{array}\right] \longrightarrow \left[ \begin{array}{@{}ccc|c@{}} 1 \amp -3 \amp 1 \amp -4 \\ 0 \amp \text{?} \amp \text{?} \amp \text{?} \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp \text{?} \amp \text{?} \\ \end{array}\right]

solution.p: We perform the transformation in two steps. First, we obtain zeros in the lower two entries of the first column. We get these zeros by adding suitable multiples of the first row to the second and third rows: \left[ \begin{array}{@{}ccc|c@{}} 1 \amp -3 \amp 1 \amp -4 \\ 3 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp 8\\ 2 \amp -2 \amp 3 \amp -1\\ \end{array}\right] \xrightarrow[\blert{-2(\text{row } 1) + \text{row }3}]{\blert{-3(\text{row } 1) + \text{row }2}} \left[ \begin{array}{@{}ccc|c@{}} 1 \amp -3 \amp 1 \amp -4 \\ 0 \amp 8 \amp -4 \amp 20 \\ 0 \amp 4 \amp 1 \amp 7 \\ \end{array}\right] Next we obtain a zero as the second entry of the third row by adding a suitable multiple of the second row. For this matrix, we add -12(\text{row }2) to \text{row }3: \left[ \begin{array}{@{}ccc|c@{}} 1 \amp -3 \amp 1 \amp -4 \\ 0 \amp 8 \amp -4 \amp 20 \\ 0 \amp 4 \amp 1 \amp 7 \\ \end{array}\right] \xrightarrow[\blert{\frac{-1}{2}(\text{row } 2) + \text{row }3}]{} \left[ \begin{array}{@{}ccc|c@{}} 1 \amp -3 \amp 1 \amp -4 \\ 0 \amp 8 \amp -4 \amp 20 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 3 \amp -3 \\ \end{array}\right] The last matrix is in upper triangular form.

subsection.title: Matrix Reduction
subsection.p: We use elementary row operations to apply Gaussian reduction to the augmented matrix of a linear system. This matrix method can be used to solve linear systems of any size and is well suited for implementation by a computer program. The method has three steps.

statement.p:
Use matrix reduction to solve the system.
x\amp {}-{}\amp 2y\amp = {}\amp -5 2x\amp {}+{}\amp 3y\amp = \amp 11

solution.p:
The augmented matrix is \left[ \begin{array}{@{}cc|c@{}} 1 \amp -2 \amp -5 \\ 2 \amp 3 \amp 11\\ \end{array}\right] We use row operations to obtain 0 in the first entry of the second row. \left[ \begin{array}{@{}cc|c@{}} 1 \amp -2 \amp -5 \\ 2 \amp 3 \amp 11\\ \end{array}\right] \xrightarrow[\blert{-2(\text{row } 1) + \text{row }2}]{} \left[ \begin{array}{@{}cc|c@{}} 1 \amp -2 \amp -5 \\ 0 \amp 7 \amp 21 \\ \end{array}\right] The last matrix is upper triangular and corresponds to the system
x\amp {}-{}\amp 2y\amp = {}\amp -5\hphantom{blankblank}\amp(1) \amp {}{}\amp 7y\amp = \amp 21\hphantom{blankblank}\amp(2)
Now we use back-substitution to solve the system. From Equation (2), y=3. Substitute 3 for y in Equation (1) to find
x - 2(\alert{3}) \amp = -5 x \amp = 1
The solution is the ordered pair (1, 3).

subsection.title: Reducing a 3\times 3 Matrix
subsection.p: Although there are many ways to reduce an augmented 3\times 3 matrix to upper triangular form, the following two-step procedure may help you organize the row operations.
If you cannot obtain nonzero entries on the diagonal, then the system does not have a unique solution; the system is either inconsistent or dependent. See Homework Problems 4548.

statement.p:
Use matrix reduction to solve the system.
2x\amp {}-{}\amp 4y\amp {}{}\amp \amp =\amp 6 3x\amp {}-{}\amp 4y\amp {}+{}\amp z \amp =\amp 8 2x\amp {}{}\amp \amp {}-{}\amp 3z\amp =\amp -11

solution.p:
The augmented matrix is
\left[ \begin{array}{@{}ccc|c@{}} 2 \amp -4\amp 0 \amp 6 \\ 3 \amp -4\amp 1 \amp 8 \\ 2 \amp 0\amp -3 \amp -11 \end{array}\right]
We obtain 1 as the first entry of the first row by multiplying each entry in the first row by \dfrac{1}{2}. This will make it easier to obtain zeros in the first entries of the second and third rows.
Next, we obtain zeros in the first entries of the second and third rows by adding suitable multiples of the first row: -3(\text{row }1) + 2~~{\Bigg\downarrow}~~3(\text{row }1) + 3

Finally, we obtain a zero in the second entry of the third row by adding -2(\text{row }2) to \text{row }3:
-2(\text{row }2) + 3~~{\Bigg\downarrow}~~\hphantom{3(\text{row }1) + 3}

The system is now in upper triangular form, and we use back-substitution to find the solution. We solve the last equation to get z=3 and substitute 3 for z in the second equation to find y=-2. Finally, we substitute 3 for z and -2 for y in the first equation to find x=-1. The solution is the ordered triple (-1,-2, 3).

statement.p:
Use matrix reduction to solve the system
x + 3z \amp = -11 2x + y + z \amp = 1 -3x - 2y = 3
Follow the suggested steps:
Write the augmented matrix for the system.
Add -2(row 1) to (row 2).
Add 3(row 1) to (row 3).
Add 2(row 2) to (row 3).
Solve the resulting system by back-substitution.

subsection.p:
It is a good idea to make the first entry in the first row equal to 1, as we did in , to simplify the calculations that follow. However, if that entry is zero we can interchange two rows. For example, to reduce the matrix \left[ \begin{array}{@{}ccc|c@{}} 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \\ 2 \amp 5 \amp 1 \amp 4 \end{array}\right] we begin by interchanging the first and second rows to obtain \left[ \begin{array}{@{}ccc|c@{}} 1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ 2 \amp 5 \amp 1 \amp 4 \end{array}\right] We then follow the two-step procedure described above to find \blert{\xrightarrow[-2(\text{row } 1) + \text{row }3]{}}
\left[ \begin{array}{@{}ccc|c@{}} 1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -5 \amp -4 \end{array}\right] \blert{\xrightarrow[-(\text{row } 2) + \text{row }3]{}} \left[ \begin{array}{@{}ccc|c@{}} 1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \amp 4 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -7 \amp -7 \end{array}\right]

subsection.title: Solving Larger Systems
subsection.p: Systems of linear equations in business and economics may involve hundreds of linear equations and hundreds of variables. The study of airflow for aircraft design can involve systems of millions of linear equations and variables. These large systems are solved using matrix methods.

statement.p:
Write the augmented matrix for the system
-w\amp {}+{} \amp x \amp {}-{}\amp y\amp {}+{}\amp z \amp =\amp 7 2w\amp {}-{}\amp 2x\amp {}-{}\amp 4y\amp {}-{}\amp 5z \amp =\amp -17 -3w\amp {}+{}\amp 9x\amp {}+{}\amp 3y\amp {}+{}\amp 6z\amp =\amp 30 4w\amp {}+{}\amp 8x\amp {}-{}\amp 2y\amp {}+{}\amp 5z\amp =\amp 17
Use matrix reduction and back-substitution to solve the system.

solution.p: The augmented matrix is \left[ \begin{array}{@{}cccc|c@{}} -1 \amp 1 \amp -1 \amp 1 \amp 7 \\ 2 \amp -2 \amp -4 \amp -5 \amp -17 \\ -3 \amp 9 \amp 3 \amp 6 \amp 30 \\ 4 \amp 8 \amp -2 \amp 5 \amp 17 \end{array}\right] We use row operations to put the matrix in upper triangular form. First, we add multiples of the first row to the rows below it to get 0s in the first column.

The second row has 0 as its second entry, so we interchange the second and third rows to put a nonzero entry in the second column. \left[ \begin{array}{@{}cccc|c@{}} -1 \amp 1 \amp -1 \amp 1 \amp 7 \\ 0 \amp 6 \amp 6 \amp 3 \amp 9 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp -6 \amp -3 \amp -3 \\ 0 \amp 12 \amp -6 \amp 9 \amp 45 \end{array}\right] Now we want 0s in the last two rows of the second column. The third row already has 0 in the second column, so we only need to add a multiple of the second row to the fourth row.
Finally, we add a multiple of the third row to the fourth row to get 0 in the third column.

This triangular matrix corresponds to the system
-w\amp {}+{} \amp x \amp {}-{}\amp y\amp {}+{}\amp z \amp =\amp 7 \amp {} {}\amp 6x\amp {}+{}\amp 6y\amp {}+{}\amp 3z \amp =\amp 9 \amp {}{}\amp \amp {} {}\amp 6y\amp {}+{}\amp 3z\amp =\amp -3 \amp {} {}\amp \amp {} {}\amp \amp {} {}\amp 12z\amp =\amp 36
which we solve by back-substitution.

From the last equation, we find z=3, and by substituting 3 for z in the third equation, we find y=-1. Next, we substitute -1 for y and 3 for z in the second equation to find x=1, and finally, we substitute x=1, y=-1, z=3 into the first equation to find w=-2.
The solution is the ordered four-tuple (-2, 1, -1, 3). We can verify that these values satisfy all four equations of the original system.

subsection.p: Our strategy for reducing 3\times 4 augmented matrices can be generalized for larger matrices, as demonstrated in . Starting with the first row, we work our way along the diagonal, using row operations to obtain nonzero entries on the diagonal and zeros below the diagonal entry.

statement.p:
Use matrix reduction to solve the system
w\amp {}+{} \amp x \amp {}+{}\amp y\amp {}+{}\amp z \amp =\amp -1 -w\amp {}+{}\amp x\amp {}-{}\amp y\amp {}+{}\amp z \amp =\amp 3 -2w\amp {}+{}\amp 10x\amp {}+{}\amp 4y\amp {}+{}\amp 7z\amp =\amp 23 3w\amp {}+{}\amp 9x\amp {}-{}\amp 3y\amp {}+{}\amp 6z\amp =\amp 0

subsection.title: Reduced Row Echelon Form
subsection.p:
The triangular matrix we obtain by row reduction is an example of row echelon formrow echelon form. In a row echelon matrix,
The first nonzero entry in any row is farther to the right than the first nonzero entry in the rows above it.
The entries directly below the first nonzero entry in any row are all zeros.
Any row consisting entirely of zeros is below all rows with any nonzero entry.
If we divide each row by its leading nonzero entry, so that the leading entry is 1, and if we use row reduction to obtain 0s above the leading 1 as well as below it, the resulting matrix is said to be in reduced row echelon formreduced row echelon form. This form is especially convenient because we do not have to use backsubstitution to finish solving the system; we can read off the solutions directly from the matrix.

For example, you can check that the matrix \left[ \begin{array}{@{}cccc|c@{}} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -3 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 4 \end{array}\right] corresponds to the system
a\amp {}+{} \amp 0b \amp {}+{}\amp 0c\amp {}+{}\amp 0d \amp =\amp -2 0a\amp {}+{}\amp b\amp {}+{}\amp 0c\amp {}+{}\amp 0d \amp =\amp 3 0a\amp {}+{}\amp 0b\amp {}+{}\amp c\amp {}+{}\amp 0d\amp =\amp -3 0a\amp {}+{}\amp 0b\amp {}+{}\amp 0c\amp {}+{}\amp d\amp =\amp 4
From this system, it is easy to read the solutions a=-2, b=3, c=-3, and d=4
